body:
Hi @lunluen, Thanks for bringing this to our attention. I will be sure to raise it in our next stand up. 

@proskurin Lets discuss this when we catch up tomorrow.

uhm, maybe the business day should be associated with each "symbol" or market

for example here in Brazil we have a business day and at another country (USA) trading the same asset (Apple for example) don't

B3 - Holiday calendar - http://www.b3.com.br/en_us/solutions/platforms/puma-trading-system/for-members-and-traders/trading-calendar/holidays/
I agree with @rspadim, it should be optional (a parameter to the function perhaps). Another example that doesn't follow business day calendars is digital assets.

and forex stop at saturday

it's a bit tricky, there's a shedule per week that should be implemented if you want it right, cause each session of trading have a procedure, some start at 8am end at 5pm, others 9am 10am... and some have a holiday where there isn't trading session. i don't know how to handle this optimized, but there're two things to think about:

1) holliday - no trading sessions from 00:00 to 23:59

2) trading session - multiperiod start time end time (sometimes a session start at end of one day and end at start of another day... at least here in brazil)

thinking about options and derivatives the (1) makes sense, and it's very important when we need things like (days to expire / 252) where 252 = trading days ≃ business days

The problem here comes from these two different time difference:
`real day difference` and `trading session difference`. (Both seems to be reasonable to use)

I found that perhaps handling the latter is out of `mlfinlab`'s scope, since a calendar object would be needed. (I'm now using `zipline`'s `trading_calendars` for this.)

So maybe just allowing users to specify their expiration time (not difference) series would be good.

Hi @lunluen , @DiePharisaer 
Thank you for your attention and contribution to mlfinlab! As you can see from discussion, various assets have different trading days/hours. It will be rather difficult to create a generic vertical barrier function for cryptos, fx, futures, stocks, etc.
However,the output of add_vertical_barrier is Pandas series with index being events index and values being vertical barriers of events. You can construct them manually depending on asset class you are using.

issue.title: improve the calculation of daily volatility in util.volatility.get_daily_vol()

repository.name: mlfinlab
repository.description: MlFinLab helps portfolio managers and traders who want to leverage the power of machine learning by providing reproducible, interpretable, and easy to use tools.

issue.body:
In util.volatility.get_daily_vol(), line 26, I think you didn't take into account the holidays or other non-trading days, I suggest replace line 26 by the following codes:

# all dates in the time series of close prices
dates = sorted(list(set([x.date() for x in close.index])))
# get number of days to the previous trading date
delta_dates = pd.Series()
delta_dates.loc[dates[0]] = datetime.timedelta(days=1)
for i in range(1, len(dates)):
    delta_dates.loc[dates[i]] = dates[i] - dates[i-1]
# previous trading date for each index in the time series of close prices
prev_dt = pd.DatetimeIndex([x-delta_dates.loc[x.date()] for x in close.index])
# get the positions of moving backward for one trading day 
df0 = close.index.searchsorted(prev_dt)
